title: Accum Func FTC: graphical line segments part - c

content.description: The continuous function f is defined on the interval −5 ≤ x ≤ 8. The graph of f, which consists of four line segments, is shown in the figure above. Let g be the function given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>x</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> <mi>x</mi> </msubsup> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mtext> </mtext> <mi>d</mi> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4B95@</annotation> </semantics> </math>.
content.question: On what intervals, if any, is the graph of g concave down? Give a reason for your answer.

frqParts.text: On what intervals, if any, is the graph of g concave down? Give a reason for your answer.

topic.text: 5.6: Determining Concavity of Functions over Their Domains

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
